;现在 7 月份的火爆数据已全部出炉，欧洲气候监测组织正式宣布这一消息：2023 年 7 月是地球有记录以来最热的一个月。

;

;哥白尼称，7 月全球平均气温为 16.95 摄氏度（62.51 华氏度），比 2019 年创下的纪录高出三分之一度欧盟太空计划的一个部门气候变化服务局周二宣布。通常情况下，全球温度记录会被打破百分之一或十分之一度，因此这个幅度是不寻常的。

;

;“这些记录对暴露在更加频繁和强烈的极端事件中的人类和地球都产生了可怕的后果， ”哥白尼副主任萨曼莎·伯吉斯说。

;

;美国西南部和墨西哥、欧洲和亚洲出现了致命的热浪。快速科学研究将其归咎于人为燃烧煤炭、石油和天然气造成的气候变化。

;

;从 7 月 2 日起，7 月的天气比之前记录的要热。气候异常温暖，以至于哥白尼和世界气象组织在结束前几天就做出了不同寻常的提前宣布，这可能是最热的一个月。周二的计算结果正式生效。

;

;本月气温比工业化前时期高 1.5 度。 2015 年，世界各国同意努力防止长期变暖 — — 不是个别月份甚至几年，而是几十年 — — 比工业化前时期高 1.5 度。

;

;上个月是如此哥白尼说，天气很热，比 1991 年至 2020 年 7 月的平均温度高 0.7 度。世界海洋温度比过去 30 年高出半度，北大西洋比平均温度高出 1.05 度。南极洲的海冰创下历史新低，比一年中这个时候的平均水平低 15%。

;

;哥白尼的记录可以追溯到 1940 年。这个温度将比美国国家海洋和大气管理局统计的任何一个月都要高。记录，他们的记录可以追溯到 1850 年。但科学家表示，这实际上是更长时期内最热的月份。

;

;“这是一个令人震惊的记录，很明显它是地球上一万年来最热的月份”，德国波茨坦气候研究所的气候科学家斯特凡·拉姆斯托夫（Stefan Rahmstorf）说。他不是哥白尼团队的成员。

;

;拉姆斯托夫引用了使用树木年轮和其他指标的研究，这些研究表明目前是自大约 10,000 年前全新世开始以来最温暖的时期。在全新世开始之前有一个冰河时代，所以说这是 12 万年来最热的记录也是合乎逻辑的，他说。

;

;“我们不应该关心 7 月，因为这是一个记录，但因为它不会保持太久，”伦敦帝国理工学院气候科学家弗里德里克·奥托说。 “这是我们改变气候程度的一个指标。我们生活在一个非常不同的世界，我们的社会不太适应在其中生活。”

;

;世界海洋也创下了新的温度记录，引发了人们对地球生态系统连锁反应的担忧。气候、海洋生物和沿海群落。

;

;根据欧盟气候观测站的数据，7月30日海洋表面温度升至20.96度。

;

;之前的记录为20.95度哥白尼气候变化服务中心的一位发言人表示，2016 年 3 月的温度为 10 度。

;

;测试的样本排除了极地地区。

;

;“我们刚刚目睹了全球气温和全球海洋表面温度，创下了新的历史记录。 -七月的时间记录。这些记录对遭受更加频繁和强烈的极端事件的人类和地球产生了可怕的后果，”欧盟哥白尼气候变化服务中心副主任萨曼莎·伯吉斯 (Samantha Burgess) 说道。

;

;“2023 年是目前第三个最热的年份今年迄今为止，全球平均气温比近期平均水平高出 0.43 摄氏度，7 月份全球平均气温比工业化前水平高出 1.5 摄氏度。

;

;“即使这只是暂时的，也表明迫切需要采取雄心勃勃的努力减少全球温室气体排放，这是这些记录背后的主要驱动力。”她说。

;

;森林大火肆虐了希腊大片地区，加拿大烧毁了 3000 万英亩（1200 万公顷）土地，而南欧、北非部分地区、美国南部和中国部分地区一直在遭受严重热浪的袭击。

;

;从中国到美国，厄尔尼诺现象如何推动热浪和极端天气

;

;最近几天袭击中国首都北京的致命降雨是自 140 年前有记录以来最严重的一次。

;

;哥白尼研究所所长卡洛·布翁坦波 (Carlo Buontempo) 早些时候曾表示，那段时期的气温“非常高”。

;

;除了这些官方记录之外，他表示，更早以前的气候代理数据（例如树木年轮或冰芯）表明，这一时期的气温可能“在过去几千年的历史中是前所未有的”。

;

;他说，可能甚至更长，“大约 10 万年”。

;

;联合国秘书长安东尼奥·古特雷斯最近发出求救电话。

;

;“气候变化是这里。这太可怕了。这只是一个开始，”古特雷斯说道，他敦促立即采取大胆行动，减少地球供暖排放。

;

;“全球变暖的时代已经结束；全球沸腾的时代已经到来。”

;

;德新社、美联社、法新社报道

;日本、美国及其盟友必须表现出“战斗决心”日本前首相麻生太郎周二在台北表示，这是阻止以武力改变台湾海峡现状的企图的一种手段。

;

;他还表示，东京需要将国防预算增加一倍，达到 2%日本执政党自民党二号人物麻生太郎在台北的一个安全论坛上发表上述言论周二。他于周一抵达台湾进行为期三天的访问。

;

;他没有具体指出北京是对现状的威胁，但强调随着人民解放军在台湾加强军事行动，局势变得更加严重。麻生太郎表示，“我们正在逐渐向紧急状态倾斜”，并补充说这种变化近年来变得更加明显。

;

;日本前首相麻生太郎抵达台湾在安全论坛上发表讲话

;

;他以解放军8月份在台湾周围进行的大规模实弹演习为例，说明局势日益严峻。此次演习是在美国前众议院议长南希·佩洛西访问台湾后进行的。

;

;他补充说，在台湾上空发射的一些弹道导弹落在了日本专属经济区（EEZ）。

;

;北京否认东京关于其导弹落在日本专属经济区的指控，理由是双方在东海该区域的边界问题上缺乏协议。

;

;北京将台湾视为其领土必须将其控制回其控制之下 — — 必要时使用武力 — — 认为佩洛西此行违反了华盛顿的一个中国政策，并严重侵犯了其主权。

;

;包括日本和美国在内的大多数国家各国不承认台湾为独立国家，但反对任何以武力单方面改变两岸现状的行为。

;

;“从来没有像现在这样，日本、台湾和美国各国需要有决心发挥强有力的威慑作用，”麻生太郎说。 “这是战斗的决心。”

;

;这位82岁的政治家表示，光花钱和拥有防御能力是不够的。

;

;“重要的是要明确他说：“对手认为我们将利用这些能力来保卫台湾、维护台海稳定。”

;

;“由于台湾是日本的近邻，我们应该首先麻生太郎表示，1982年的马岛战争就是一个例子，单纯地发出强有力的威慑信息是失败的。他说，如果当时的英国首相玛格丽特·撒切尔向阿根廷明确表示英国将不惜一切代价保卫福克兰群岛，战争就不会发生。

;

;“因此，有必要麻生太郎说：“现在对我们来说最重要的是包括台海在内的地区不应该发生战争。”

;麻生太郎还借此机会表示，日本必须增加国防预算，以增强其威慑能力。

;

;他表示，日本需要“为可能发生的战争做好准备”，并且邻国正在“迅速增强军备”，并补充说，日本目前正处于“二战结束以来最严峻、最复杂的安全环境”。

;

;他表示，日本用于实施国防发展的预算预计到 2027 财年，防卫预算将从 2023 年的 6.8 万亿日元增至 43 万亿日元（约合 3070 亿美元）。

;

;“我们将确保国防预算达到每年 2 万亿日元的水平。占 GDP 的 1%，高于目前的 1%，”他补充道，2% 的水平与北约的国防支出目标类似。

;

;“这是我们对现状的回应，”他说。

;

;从“盾牌到剑”？中国对日本的军事重心发出警告

;

;12月，日本宣布将打破其传统的和平防卫政策，购买更多进攻性武器，包括巡航导弹，以增强其能力。

;

;麻生太郎受 Prospect 基金会邀请，在其区域安全会议凯达格兰论坛上担任主旨发言人。台北政府资助的基金会因被视为推动台湾独立而受到北京的制裁。

;

;麻生太郎不久后在新北的已故台湾总统李登辉的坟墓前悼念了他他抵达台湾，是自 1972 年东京与台北断绝外交关系以来访问台湾的日本执政党中最资深的政治家。

;

;周二，他会见了台湾领导人蔡英文、副总统蔡英文。总统赖清德和其他高级官员。

;富士康科技集团深圳子公司富士康工业互联网 (FII)，据台湾《经济日报》报道，随着这家全球最有价值的公司继续将其制造供应链从中国转移出去，将“独家”向苹果供应越南制造的服务器，用于培训和测试人工智能（AI）服务

;

;该报告援引消息人士的话说，富士康是全球最大的电子产品合同制造商和苹果 iPhone 的主要组装商，也是这家美国科技巨头数据中心使用的服务器的最大供应商。周一。它还表示，富士康（正式名称为鸿海精密工业）约占全球服务器市场的 43％。

;A Hong Kong judge has overturned an order requiring the justice department to pay for a photographer's legal fees in a case stemming from the 2019 anti-government protests, after finding the man's actions at the time were unwarranted.

;

;Madam Justice Esther Toh Lye-ping on Tuesday told the High Court that Swiss-born Marc Gerard Progin did not deserve to be compensated despite being acquitted for charges of aiding and abetting disorder, because he had no reason to stand in the way of a mainland Chinese man who was subsequently assaulted by radicals.

;

;Prosecutors had not sought to reverse the acquittal, only asking the court to quash the earlier decision that ordered them to compensate Progin for his legal battle.

;

;Hong Kong court orders retrial of 4 acquitted of rioting during 2019 protests

;

;But Toh implied the Department of Justice would have had a reasonable chance of success had they lodged a full appeal, saying the trial court had let Progin walk free based on an erroneous analysis of the evidence.

;

;Progin landed himself in court three years ago after trying to find the best angles to photograph then JPMorgan Chase employee Lin Nan, who was targeted by protesters during a lunchtime demonstration in Central on October 4, 2019.

;

;Prosecutors had alleged the freelance photographer instigated violence against the Xi'an-born man by closing the door to his office tower, standing in front of him and preventing him from leaving. Progin maintained he was merely trying to “take a very good photo”.

;

;Lin, who stood still and stared at Progin after being blocked initially, was punched from behind by a black-clad protester, before another assailant hurled an umbrella at him. Police were unable to arrest the two suspects.

;

;Justice department appeals against judge's refusal to ban 'Glory to Hong Kong'

;

;Magistrate Stephanie Tsui May-har had found Progin not guilty of aiding and abetting disorder, but remarked that his behaviour was “highly suspicious”.

;

;She noted that even though Progin had obstructed the bank worker, the latter could still return to his workplace unimpeded, and the few seconds in delay could hardly be of “any meaningful assistance to the crowd to continue their commotion”.

;

;The magistrate earlier granted a cost order against the Department of Justice, pointing out the accused was not affiliated with anyone at the protest and could not have predicted the attacks on the victim.

;

;But Toh on Tuesday stressed those considerations were irrelevant, as Progin could still be held liable if he paid no regard to whether social order would be disrupted by his actions.

;

;Hong Kong actor Gregory Wong tells court going to Legco was 'foolish' amid social unrest

;

;“What was relevant was the fact that, as he admitted, there was a hostile crowd following [Lin]. It was therefore a situation ripe for rowdy and aggressive action against [him]. Anyone living in Hong Kong in October 2019 would have realised that,” Toh said.

;

;But she clarified that her task was only to review the decision over costs, saying: “As the prosecution had not [appealed] the acquittal of [the accused], I am only dealing with the review of the costs order.”

;

;Toh said Progin had clearly incriminated himself through his actions, as he had already taken many photos of Lin before standing in his path.

;

;“I have no hesitation whatsoever, in saying that therefore, [the accused] should not be allowed his costs of the trial, on the review, and on this appeal,” the judge concluded.

;

;Acquitted defendants are in principle entitled to be compensated out of public coffers for costs incurred in court proceedings, unless they are deemed to have brought suspicion upon themselves or misled prosecutors over the strength of their allegations.

; Tue, 08 Aug 2023 19:20:01 +0800 Second son of Thailand’s King Maha Vajiralongkorn makes surprise return after 27 years away: ‘a dream to be back’https://www.scmp.com/news/asia/southeast-asia/article/3230404/second-son-thailands-king-maha-vajiralongkorn-makes-surprise-return-after-27-years-away-dream-be?utm_source=rss_feed

;The second-eldest son of Thailand's King Maha Vajiralongkorn visited a childcare centre for underprivileged families on Tuesday during a surprise visit to the kingdom, the first time he has been back in his homeland in 27 years.

;

;The trip by Vacharaesorn Vivacharawongse, 42, comes at a fraught time for the Thai royal family, with the monarch's eldest daughter in a coma since December.

;

;Vacharaesorn, who works at a law firm in New York, visited the Foundation for Slum Child Care, which is supported by the royal family, and greeted well-wishers.

;

;Clad in jeans and a casual black shirt, he posed for photographs in front of portraits of his father and his grandfather, King Bhumibol Adulyadej, who died in 2016 after a 70-year reign.

;

;“I am delighted to return … I have been away for a long time, 27 years,” Vacharaesorn told reporters at the Bangkok foundation.

;

;“It is like a dream come true to be back,” he said.

;

;The Royal Palace has not commented on the visit. The Palace Household Bureau did not respond to requests for comment.

;

;Many Thais have been surprised by Vacharaesorn's return. A picture of him in a “tuk-tuk” autorickshaw in Bangkok, that he posted on Monday on his Facebook page, which has more than 80,000 followers, received tens of thousands of likes.

;

;On X, the social media platform formerly known as Twitter, the hashtag #SonOfTenReturnToThailand was mentioned almost 390,000 times. His father's formal title is King Rama X.

;

;Those who saw Vacharaesorn were impressed.

;

;“I am very moved, he has been away for a long time. To me he is still a member of the royal family,” said Angsana Seeprasit, 66.

;

;Vacharaesorn is the second of four sons of King Vajiralongkorn's second wife, Sujarinee Vivacharawongse, a former actress whom the then-crown prince divorced in 1996.

;

;He has no formal royal title though he technically retains a status bestowed when he was a child as a grandson of a monarch.

;

;He, his mother, three brothers and one sister were estranged after the 1996 divorce, in which his mother was publicly accused of adultery, and they moved abroad.

;

;Vacharaesorn's younger sister was later re-embraced by the royal family and given the royal title Princess Sirivannavari Nariratana. She is a fashion designer and equestrian who competed in the 2014 Asian Games for Thailand.

;

;The thrice-divorced King Vajiralongkorn has seven children. He is married to Queen Suthida, his former chief bodyguard whom he wed days before his coronation in 2019.

;

;The 71-year-old monarch has not named an official heir.

;

;In late December, the king's eldest child, Princess Bajrakitiyabha Narendira Debyavati, 44, collapsed due to a severe heart condition. She remains in a coma.

; Tue, 08 Aug 2023 19:20:01 +0800 Taiwan’s exports fall for 11th straight month, as mainland China’s weakened world-factory role hit shipmentshttps://www.scmp.com/economy/global-economy/article/3230388/taiwans-exports-fall-11th-straight-month-mainland-chinas-weakened-world-factory-role-hit-shipments?utm_source=rss_feed

;Taiwan's exports fell for the 11th straight month in July due to weak demand from mainland China and Hong Kong and a nagging lull in global consumption of hi-tech equipment.

;

;The island's Ministry of Finance on Tuesday reported a 10.4 per cent drop in exports last month, compared to July 2022, to US$38.73 billion.

;

;Taiwan counted mainland China and Hong Kong as its largest export market last month at US$13.42 billion, shipping a range of parts for final assembly and re-export.

;

;But Mainland China has struggled to smooth out its economic recovery after removing its coronavirus pandemic controls.

;

;And Taiwan's shipments to mainland China and Hong Kong in July fell by 16.3 per cent in July, year on year, the ministry data showed.

;

;Last month, China's official manufacturing purchasing managers' index remained in contraction for a fourth straight month, while its exports fell by 14.5 per cent compared with a year earlier.

;

;“For mainland China, the world factory role is being weakened, and that's hurting Taiwan's exports,” said Liang Kuo-yuan, the retired founder of Taipei-based think tank, the Yuanta-Polaris Research Institute.

;

;“Taiwan's intermediate goods aren't doing great.”

;

;The island's government has said a recovery in exports may not occur until September at the earliest, or as late as November, as orders pick up for the traditionally busy Christmas season.

;

;But July's data also showed Taiwan's exports of electronic components, including semiconductors, fell by 7.9 per cent compared to the same month a year ago. Electronic components are a flagship for the island, with the sector still worth US$15.61 billion last month.

;

;The fall in exports in July “points towards ongoing softness in semiconductor demand, particularly in the business segment,” said Heron Lim, an economist with Moody's Analytics in Singapore.

;

;“China's troubled recovery has been capping Taiwan exports, as well,” Lim added.

;

;Frenemies? Once tech rivals, Taiwan and South Korea seek low risk collaboration

;

;The uneven economic trajectory in mainland China, plus high inflation and fears of recession in the West, have reduced Taiwan's exports every month for almost a year, with the pressure set to remain, economists said.

;

;Elsewhere, Taiwan's exports to the United States fell by 3.3 per cent in July.

;

;Taiwan's imports of specialised equipment to make semiconductor chips also eased, falling by 31.5 per cent, year on year.

;

;The drop points to a fall in global demand for consumer electronics that use chips made in Taiwan, Standard Chartered Bank's Taipei-based economist Tony Phoo said.

;

;“Equipment imports could be revealing with a downtrend for several months already,” Phoo said.

;

;“If we continue to see this soft data into the third quarter of this year, then chances are that third quarter growth numbers are going to stay soft,” he said. “It also portends that the global tech outlook is unlikely to improve any time soon.”

;

;Chip makers such as Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company, the world's largest contractor in the industry, supplies the likes of Apple, Nvidia and other major brands.

;

;Fellow Taiwanese chip maker United Microelectronics Corporation said last week that its net sales in July fell by 23.21 per cent, year on year.

;

;Taiwan trims 2023 GDP forecast, but AI, foldable phones and India offer support

;

;Taiwan's Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics already lowered its 2023 gross domestic product forecast to 2.04 per cent in May.

;

;The economy edged up in the second quarter, however, after entering recession in the first three months of 2023.

;

;Elsewhere, Taiwan's shipments of petrochemical products dropped by 28.8 per cent, while exports of chemicals eased by 31.2 per cent.

;

;Moody's Analytics expects Taiwan's export orders to be “tepid” through September, Lim added.

;

;The prolonged downward spiral became clear in June, said Darson Chiu, a research fellow with the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research in Taipei, although some economists had forecast in early 2023 that a turnaround would take place in the second half of the year.

;

;“Regardless of whether they are hi-tech products or traditional manufactured products, their export orders all fell in double-digits in June,” Chiu said.

;

;“Obviously, not all products will sell well in July, August, and even September.”

;Shangyou News reported on August 6 that biblical-scale flooding has affected about 2.22 million people in the city, forcing the evacuation of one in six residents.

;

;In response, more than 150 civilian rescue groups from across the country came to the aid of flood victims. This reaction – and the tales of heroism it entailed – has inspired millions of people on mainland social media.

;

;Children first

;

;Rescue workers who prioritised women and children touched many online.

;

;Video footage showed a male rescue worker in a life jacket holding a 40-day-old infant, while next to him was the baby's mother carrying two big bags.

;

;“Those with children first,” a voice repeatedly called out.

;

;As soon as the rescue worker and the mother and child reached safety, a couple gave up their seats for them.

;

;This melted the hearts of many people, with one saying: “It is so touching. Thanks for protecting our people,” while another commented: “I wish everyone to be safe.”

;

;Man's best friend

;

;Another trending story is that of a young man who delayed the rescue workers for two to three minutes by returning home to save his dog.

;

;Following his own rescue, it dawned on the man that he had left his dog behind at home. He immediately ran back to save his dog, in a three-minute act of love that has impressed countless people online.

;

;While many empathised with the man's display of love for his dog, some online observers felt that the man should not have wasted the time of rescue workers which could have been spent on saving humans.

;

;Saving its bacon, with biscuits

;

;The life of a small three-month-old pig, weighing about 30kg was saved after it followed a rescue worker who tempted and fed it with biscuits.

;

;When the worker saw the pig in floodwater one-metre deep, he fed it biscuits. As the situation developed it became clear that the porker was not going to leave the rescuers as long as there were biscuits available, facilitating the animal's journey to safety.

;

;Rescuers said that the pig was terrified and helpless so they gave it to a villager who stayed behind in his home despite the flooding to look after.

;

;“Oh, it melts my heart,” one person said on Douyin, while another wrote: “Everything in the world has a soul that belongs.”

;

;Oodles of noodles

;

;The story of a 43-year-old man who voluntarily prepared noodles for local rescuers and residents has gone viral.

;

;The man, surnamed Zhao, from the Shenying rescue team of Henan province in central China arrived in Zhuozhou on August 2 to help with flood relief efforts.

;

;He had brought the hand-pulled hui mian noodles from his hometown and set up a noodle corner on the street providing 13 giant pots of the free food to flood-affected residents and rescuers.

;

;In the viral video, Zhao can be seen cooking a giant pot of noodles and distributing them to people lined up for a share. Zhao tells them: “Elderly people, children and rescuers are first.”

;

;The Chinese public have praised his selfless deed, with many people labelling him a folk hero.

;

;Farewell to heroes of Henan

;

;Images of Zhuozhou citizens lining up on the street to say goodbye to the rescue teams from the neigbouring Henan province provided a perfect bookend to the countless feel-good stories resulting from the floods.

;

;In a viral video, crowds of people can be seen lining the streets waving banners in thanks and appreciation as the rescue workers begin their journey home.

;

;“You are all amazing. I will have to visit Henan,” an unidentified woman says in the video.

;

;Mainland social media has been captivated by the moment. One online observer said: “Thumbs up to Henan,” while another said: “I want to visit Henan too.”
